I just published an essay, Reading Fiction as Self-Renewal, at Medium
Historical novels and novels based on legend/myth can help readers imagine the experience of living through not just the stories told, but, by extension, an entire era or entire cycle of legend/myth.
Stories that give the reader a subjective experience through the consciousness of ""living"" characters are fundamentally ""true"", whether such events ever happened or not.

Stories that consist solely of plot, simply recounting events, showing no awareness of the thoughts, feelings, and perspectives of the characters, are not ""fiction"" in this sense, even though the events chronicled are invented.

We can view narrative as ranging in a spectrum from Tristram Shandy to the mere chronicling of facts, from ultra-subjective to objective. The aim of fiction is subjectivity, and the aim of science is objectivity

Characters who ""come alive"" in fiction give readers opportunities to experience and understand the events of the story as if they were in it and can, at the same time, reawaken readers' childlike experience of their own lives.

Children are born with unique awareness, imagining everything is alive and sentient, like themselves. They then learn to see the world and others and even themselves as things, subject to physical laws, predictable, with little or no control over their destiny.

Free will and determinism are both true at once. One of the aims of fiction is to invite the reader to explore the subjective reality of others, which is rich in possibilities, and to appreciate the dual nature of human consciousness.

An event as experienced from inside is a different reality than that same event seen from afar. The event as lived is caused by human intent, could have turned out differently, and is unique. The event seen from afar is determined, predictable, and ordinary.
